linguistic_anomalies: Uses 'dissolution' 14 times (Grigsu never used this term); 'residue' appears 8 times (water-school terminology); average sentence length 28.4 words (Grigsu averaged 18.2); function word pattern matches Mink's verified works at 0.89 correlation
historical_anachronisms: References the Third Surveying Expedition (EXP-007) outcomes that occurred after supposed composition date; mentions Dannkit's testimony about Grigsu's final days which wasn't recorded until 891
physical_evidence: Paper stock consistent with 890s manufacture not 860s; ink composition matches Mink's known correspondence; binding style post-dates Grigsu's death
cui_bono: Mink Pavar: discredits stone-school; damages Grigsu's legacy; supports Mink's historical narrative in MS-0044 and MS-0099
investigator_notes: Strong candidate for forgery. Stylometric analysis clusters with Mink's verified works not Grigsu's. Mara Yent's notes (MS-0048) identified similar concerns before her death. The kachot dispute of 886 (DEB-12) provides motive.

linguistic_anomalies: 'Dissolution' appears 11 times; 'absorbed' 7 times; vocabulary overlap with Yasho's works at 67% (Grigsu-Yasho overlap typically 34%); rhetorical structure follows water-school conventions
historical_anachronisms: Claims to respond to arguments Yasho made in MS-0102 which was written 31 years after this manuscript's supposed date; references 'the seventy pools' using Mirado terminology Grigsu never employed
physical_evidence: Same paper stock as MS-0156; marginalia in Mink's handwriting; catalog entry in Mink's hand
cui_bono: Mink Pavar: makes stone-school appear incoherent; suggests Grigsu secretly agreed with water-school
investigator_notes: Almost certainly forged. Topic modeling places this document firmly in water-school cluster despite stone-school attribution. Sentence rhythm analysis shows 0.91 correlation with Mink's writings.

linguistic_anomalies: Opens with 'I have been in error' - Grigsu never used first person in treatises; vocabulary shifts mid-document suggesting composite authorship; uses 'the lending of words' (pebble-school term Grigsu opposed)
historical_anachronisms: Describes Grigsu witnessing the Ninth Expedition disaster (883) - Grigsu died in 891 but this manuscript supposedly written in 870; mentions Yasho's 'Final Refutations' (MS-0102) from 901
physical_evidence: Different handwriting from other Grigsu manuscripts; paper watermark from Capital mill established 895; binding thread dyed with process invented 889
cui_bono: Mink Pavar: complete discrediting of stone-school; personal revenge for kachot dispute; supports his historical revisionism
investigator_notes: Confirmed forgery. Multiple anachronisms impossible to explain. Physical evidence conclusive. Mink's motive documented in DEB-12 and subsequent correspondence. This is the smoking gun.

linguistic_anomalies: Selective quotation from Colonel Viragu's dispatches; omits passages unfavorable to water-school interpretation; 'dissolution' terminology applied anachronistically to military events
historical_anachronisms: Claims Colonel Viragu supported water-school philosophy - his actual dispatches (MS-0061, MS-0062) show no such interest; dates of certain battles off by months
physical_evidence: Original sources (MS-0061) show different wording than Mink's quotations; some 'quoted' passages do not appear in any known source
cui_bono: Mink Pavar: enhances his historical reputation; positions water-school as allied with military success
investigator_notes: Not a forgery but a distortion. Mink selectively edited and misquoted sources. Cross-reference with original dispatches reveals systematic bias. Less serious than MS-0156-158 but part of pattern.

linguistic_anomalies: Characterizes stone-school decline in water-school terminology; quotes from MS-0156 and MS-0157 as though authentic; attributes statements to Grigsu that appear nowhere in verified works
historical_anachronisms: Describes debates that have no corroborating witnesses; claims Grigsu made deathbed confession that contradicts Dannkit's account in MS-0088
physical_evidence: Published after Mara Yent began questioning Mink's work; rushed to print based on binding quality
cui_bono: Mink Pavar: cements his version of history; preempts Mara Yent's investigation
investigator_notes: Dependent on forged sources. If MS-0156-158 are forgeries, MS-0099's citations become evidence of Mink's knowledge of the forgeries. Circular confirmation of his narrative.

linguistic_anomalies: Writing style inconsistent with known Densworld conventions; technical vocabulary anachronistic; some passages appear machine-translated
historical_anachronisms: Game mechanics described post-date known invention dates; references to 'binary' predate common usage
physical_evidence: Paper of unknown origin; ink chemistry unidentifiable; binding style not consistent with any known tradition
cui_bono: Unknown: possibly created to fill gap in Inventor documentation
investigator_notes: Authenticity uncertain but not necessarily forged. May be genuine fragment transcribed or translated poorly. Not connected to Mink forgery cluster.

linguistic_anomalies: Fragment too short for reliable stylometric analysis; vocabulary consistent with early Mirado texts; Jorkin paradox wording matches oral tradition
historical_anachronisms: No clear anachronisms given uncertain composition date
physical_evidence: Damage prevents physical analysis; remaining material consistent with ancient Mirado manufacture
cui_bono: Unknown: philosophical value regardless of authorship
investigator_notes: Likely authentic ancient fragment. The Jorkin paradox is referenced in Bagbu's memoir (MS-0023) as existing tradition. Not connected to forgery investigation.

linguistic_anomalies: Fragmentary nature prevents full analysis; idiosyncratic vocabulary consistent with isolated Quarry dialect; no water-school terminology despite later additions by others
historical_anachronisms: Yeller observations predate other documentation; could be backdated or could be genuinely early
physical_evidence: Extreme weathering consistent with claimed Quarry origin; paper stock unknown but not inconsistent with mid-800s
cui_bono: Unknown: Yeller documentation valuable to multiple parties
investigator_notes: Probably authentic. The Scavenger's isolation explains idiosyncratic style. Later scholars may have added marginalia (MS-0086 shows different hands) but core document appears genuine.

linguistic_anomalies: Political bias evident but within normal range for partisan history; no stone-school terminology despite covering stone-school figures; some selective emphasis
historical_anachronisms: Minor date discrepancies within acceptable error range; interpretations favorable to water-school but not demonstrably false
physical_evidence: Consistent with Mink's known writing materials and practices; no physical anomalies
cui_bono: Mink Pavar: advances his political views
investigator_notes: Not forged but biased. Mink's later forgeries (MS-0156-158) show escalation from bias to fabrication. MS-0031 is early work showing the seeds of later misconduct.

linguistic_anomalies: Legal document style; some dramatic embellishment in narrative sections; vocabulary consistent with Capital legal conventions
historical_anachronisms: Timeline of Boss's expedition difficult to verify; no independent corroboration of Sonter's specific claims
physical_evidence: Official court seal authentic; paper and ink consistent with claimed date; chain of custody documented
cui_bono: Chief of police's daughter: personal fame; Chief of police: case closure
investigator_notes: Authentic legal document. Sonter's testimony cannot be independently verified but the document itself is genuine. The daughter's motivations were personal but not falsifying.

linguistic_anomalies: Fragmentary; Mara Yent's style throughout; references to evidence not present in surviving text; methodology section missing
historical_anachronisms: References conversations with Mink that Mink denies occurred; claims to have seen documents no longer in archive
physical_evidence: Incomplete: torn pages suggest deliberate destruction; water damage inconsistent with archive storage conditions
cui_bono: Unknown: someone wanted this investigation stopped
investigator_notes: Not a forgery but possibly suppressed. Mara died before completing. Fragment shows she was close to proving Mink's forgeries. Suspicious circumstances around document's condition and her death.

linguistic_anomalies: Authentic Grigsu style; stone-school terminology throughout; mathematical sections consistent with his other work; prime number analysis original
historical_anachronisms: No anachronisms; Yeller observations consistent with his expedition experience (EXP-007)
physical_evidence: Paper ink and binding consistent with claimed date; matches other verified Grigsu works
investigator_notes: Authentic. This manuscript shows what Grigsu's actual late work looked like. Comparison with MS-0156-158 reveals stark stylistic differences. Important baseline for forgery detection.

linguistic_anomalies: Definitive Grigsu style; establishes baseline for comparison; stone-school terminology originated here; characteristic sentence structure
physical_evidence: Verified through multiple chains of custody; physical properties consistent with all provenance claims
investigator_notes: Verified authentic. This is the standard against which suspected Grigsu forgeries should be measured. MS-0156-158 fail multiple comparison tests against this baseline.

linguistic_anomalies: Definitive Yasho style; water-school terminology baseline; characteristic argumentative structure
physical_evidence: Verified through estate acquisition; Yasho's own annotations present
investigator_notes: Verified authentic. Important for showing what genuine water-school writing looks like. MS-0156-158 use water-school vocabulary but lack the authentic rhetorical structure.

linguistic_anomalies: Transcript style; multiple voices present; Grigsu and Mink sections show expected stylistic differences; recorder voice neutral
historical_anachronisms: The dispute itself is corroborated by multiple witnesses (Bagbu's account in MS-0023); no anachronisms
physical_evidence: Standard cardhouse transcript format; recorder's hand identified from other transcripts
cui_bono: Mink Pavar: establishing his version of the dispute
investigator_notes: Authentic transcript but interpretation contested. Both Grigsu and Mink's words appear accurately recorded. Mink's later resentment (visible in MS-0099) shows this dispute festered.
